parts.title: Wittgenstein's Picture Theory
parts.body: Wittgenstein's Picture Theory: Wittgenstein was deeply troubled by questions of meaning and logic. In his work, the Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus, he developed the "picture theory" of meaning. It emphasized that language succeeds in representing facts by picturing them. He likened representing facts through language to arranging toy cars in the positions of real cars in an accident. He believed that each meaningful sentence could be translated into an ideal language. This ideal language would be composed of simple propositions, such as the words "or," "and," and "not." This work was influential in 20th-century philosophy.
